Award.AwardTitle: SCC-Planning: Enhancing Water Resource Management and Infrastructure Improvement through Sensing, Computation, and Community Engagement

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Constructing and maintaining an effective water supply and management system is paramount to enhancing the resiliency of our communities, promoting economic growth in agriculture-dominant regions, and ensuring food security locally, nationally, and worldwide. There are four major socio-technical challenges facing our water systems: i) water shortage, ii) lack of technical and infrastructural integration, iii) disconnects in supply and conservation needs, and iv) inefficient resource management strategies. Stakeholder-driven fundamental research is necessary to overcome these challenges. This interdisciplinary planning project aims to establish a community of stakeholders with the objectives of (1) identifying the grand challenging problems in water supply chain, (2) sharing experiences of modernizing water infrastructures across counties, and (3) addressing the hurdles preventing effective water resource management, especially in the Southwest region of the United States. This capacity building project brings stakeholders including researchers, consumers, water supply companies, and authorities together to share their experience, strengths, and weakness, and to develop a short- and long-term strategic plan for addressing the challenges pertinent to water resource management. The proposed plan will offer a model for states and counties with similar circumstances and thus build a connected community, where stakeholders share their concerns and experiences.

Specifically, this planning project will hold (1) a focus group-based study to discuss the persisting, urgent problems among water stakeholders, and (2) a workshop where stakeholders will have the opportunity to learn about challenges from a range of perspective, share advances in water technology and infrastructure, and discover potential research opportunities to address the problems exposed. Thus, this planning project will engage a wide range of water-related stakeholders and promote effective water conservation strategies to protect the region's water supply. By improving water use efficiency, the project will support efforts to meet growing water needs and minimize competition between food, energy, and municipal sectors. The resulting water usage model will help communities develop better programs for water conservation and improve water use efficiency. The project will develop a central area of focus in the water community for future research efforts, and lay the groundwork for much more fruitful collaboration between stakeholders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of this project were to (1) Investigate water resource management problems in three business sectors: Agriculture, Oil & Gas industries and Water municipals, especially the data and information needs of rural communities. (2) Create an information sharing platform to enable stakeholders to share knowledge, experience, and data with the goal of improving water supply resilience, (3) Offer a professional development workshop for water community, with the goal of (i) reporting the results of the research performed in this project, (ii) sharing experiences of modernizing water infrastructures across counties, (iii) providing training opportunities for participants to adopt the advanced water management techniques in their normal practice, and (iv) establishing an interconnected community of water stakeholders working towards the common goal of improving water supply resilience in otherwise disconnected groundwater-dependent rural economies.

 

To accomplish the first objective, the research team recruited water experts and water stakeholders and organized three focus groups, two water plant tours and several follow-up meetings:

a)     For the agriculture domain, the research team worked with the Texas Alliance for Water Conservation and recruited 13 participants and formed a focus group, to discuss the persistent irrigation problems that farmers are facing across the west Texas region. According to the outcome discussion of the focus group: (1) roughly, two thirds of the participants had meters installed in their irrigation wells; and (2) 55% of the producers used sensors or drone technology for precision agriculture. The research team further explored the influence of irrigation water for optimized crop production, and published the results in the 23rd Pacific-Asia Conference on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining.  

b)     For the Oil & Gas industry, the research team recruited 13 participants from Midland, TX and surrounding counties, with the goal of understanding the challenges associated with water professionals about their work. The focus group discussion showed in the Oil & Gas industry, the most challenges in data acquisition and handling includes: (1) no radio or cell coverage in an area, (2) volume of data, (3) missing data, (4) manual data entry and transcription, (5) lack of data analytics experts, cost, and (6) insufficient bandwidth.

c)     For the municipal group, the research team collaborated with local seven cities surrounding Lubbock, TX, to explore ways to construct and maintain an effective water supply and management system. The focus group discussion revealed that 60% of cities have installed smart meters, which were used for billing process, analyzing water use, promotion water conservation and management of demands. For the west Texas municipal water sectors, the professional water management experts are looking into the following technologies for further re-structure their infrastructure: Aquifer Storage and Recovery; Inland Brackish groundwater desalination; Purchase of water rights from agriculture; Reuse of stormwater; and Reuse of Wastewater. The results about saturated thickness were published in Visualization in Environmental Sciences 2018.

 

To accomplish the second objective, the research team developed an online platform for water resource management with the following functionalities: (a) a Bird?s-eye view of Texas?s underground water supply on the map; (b) forecasting the future underground water supply using deep learning-based approaches for time series analysis; (c) extracting the concern flow from different water stakeholders in Texas by mining social media data, which helps understanding the key issues during different time periods; (d) classifying users? posts and questions, experiences automatically, and connects water stakeholders in different domains. These results were published in 2018 IEEE/ACM International Conference on Advances in Social Networks Analysis and Mining.

 

To accomplish the third objective, the research team organized a workshop on Water Resource Management in Smart and Connected Communities at Texas Tech University. The participants included stakeholders of three communities (Water municipals, Agricultures, Oil & Gas industries), regional experts in academia and industry, city managers, researchers and students. The workshop had several components and sessions: (a) invited experts from three water domains to give presentations, sharing the advanced technologies and challenges in each filed; (b) reported the discoveries from three focus group discussions (municipal water management, agriculture water usage, and oil & gas water recycling). (c) demonstrated the water information sharing platform to the audience; (d) organized a panel discussion, discussing how to make smarter water systems. Through the workshop, the water community and stakeholders (i) gained a better understanding of existing critical and common problems in the water science domain, current approaches, practices, and future needs among community members; (ii) understood data and smart technologies for better water planning at both short and long-term; (iii) developed a central area of focus in the water community, and laid the groundwork for much more fruitful collaboration between stakeholders, working towards the common goal of improving water supply resilience.
